no. a subspace of Rn must have linear combination of vectors with n components. Vectors in R1 do not have the same amount of components as in R2. For example [2, 1, 0] belongs in R3, not in R2, even though you can see it in it's entirety in the xy plane.

A subspace of a vector space is a set of vectors that is closed under addition and multiplication. Using this definition, take a linear combination of two vectors in R2 and you will end up with the entire vector space, R2 which fits our definition of subspace.

The way the ideas were tied together in the end - simply beautiful.

Nothing's wrong, you do get a plane in R2 as well (except if the vectors are on the same line, in that case you get a line). The difference is, in R2 you can only get the same plane each time (the whole R2). In R3, you can get different planes because each plane can be rotated differently, but they all need to go through the zero vector.

@yoyolol22    Yes, you do.  You need linear algebra for computer vision. Computer vision falls under machine learning.
@judepope6196  damn I hate matrices

@yoyolol22  I too hated matrices and geometry (here in Brazil we study GAAL, which means, Analytical Geometry and Linear Algebra). But think of matrices as a collection of vectors, say column vectors.   What I mean is, instead of studying or using a vector at a time we use a collection of them at once. Think of a vector as a single, very well defined and important, purpose. With this collection, say a toolbox, you could do amazing things.   It may not help, but it did help me start loving LinAlg. Again, reinforcing the idea. Instead of using only one tool (a number), we can use a lot of them at once. That's why matrices appear everywhere, even in probability and statistics.   An example is the multivariate Gaussian distribution.

Can someone explain why exactly is it (P)(A)=(L)(U)? I mean if I follow the steps one by one, its    (P1)(E1)(A) = (U1),   (where E1 is the first row operation elementary matrix, P1 is the permutation matrix if any row exchange follows E1 and U1 is the resulting matrix) then, (P2)(E2)(P1)(E1)(A) = (U2) then, (P3)(E3)(P2)(E2)(P1)(E1)(A) = (U3) ... so on .... finally, (Pn)(En)...(P3)(E3)(P2)(E2)(P1)(E1)(A) = (Un) = (U) Now this means  A = ((Pn)(En)...(P3)(E3)(P2)(E2)(P1)(E1))' (U),  (' denotes inverse here) How does this convert to PA=LU ???????

no, a lower matrix has zeros below the diagonal,
Riken Maharjan Upper diagonal matrices have zeros below the diagonal.  Lower diagonal matrices have zeros above the diagonal.

Yes, it will shift, but once we said that we are working with vector space containing ONLY one vector  [0, 0], you can use only what's inside of your vector space. You cannot use non-zero vectors because you  don't have them in your space.
Nice explanation. Thank you.

I bet you already found the answer to this one. The rule states that you can add any combination of vectors in the same vector space. So in this case, where the zero vector is the sub space, the only vector you can add is the zero vector.

+Juan Pérez It's a symbolic notation. ℝⁿ means "n-dimensional Euclidian space", not "ℝ to the n'th power".
+Weierstrass well it kinda means "to the nth power" with regards to the cartesian product.  ℝⁿ = ℝ x ℝ x ... x ℝ with n ℝs, just like with normal powers of the natural numbers.

Symmetric matrice is the one that has its "top left to bottom right" diagonal to be the line of symmetric - it means that the component Aij equals Aji. Then you can see that A11(which is top left) is not necessarily equal A33 (which is bottom right)
around 21:50

I think that's the consequence of using a 3x2 matrix in his example. If he had used a 3x3 matrix, then the column space would be all of R^3, but since he used a 3x2 matrix, with only two vectors in 3D dimensions, that makes a plane.

for example I could say suppose you want to create a subspace out of 2 vectors (1,0,0) and (0,1,0). So that subspace includes all the vectors of the form (a,b,0) where a,b are arbitrary. Now you can easily notice that this subspace of all (a,b,0) is not the whole R^3, because (0,0,1) is in R^3 but not in (a,b,0) subspace.
Quantumlogik As others said above, 2 lines in the 3 dimensional space would give you only a plane. You'd need 3 vectors to fill all of R^3, just as a single vector would only give you a line.

***** Dustin Charles Lecture 5 had recording problems during class and was re-recorded in an empty classroom a short time later. The problem for lecture 4 is different. These videos were originally published in 2005 as quarter screen (320x240) RealMedia files. Years later we remastered them in Standard Definition. The tape for lecture 4 was lost, so remastering was not possible. Sadly, the quarter screen version is all we have left of it.

oh ok, that's right, there are not 6 different row swaps but there are 6 different ways to "reorder the matrix."  thanks. lande
you can also swap 1,2 and then 3 with one of them.

There are not n! distinct ways to reorder the matrix.  Only n!/2 I believe.  Because swapping rows 1 and 3 is the same thing as swapping rows 3 and 1.  Consider a 3 x 3 matrix does not have 6 different row swaps.  i can swap 1,2 1,3, or 2,3 that's all.
